prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section.

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Revised paragraph:

vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits

response.output: Genes collaborate within context-specific networks to carry out various functions (PMID: 19104045; DOI: 10.1038/ng.3259). Variations in these genes can alter their functional role and, on a broader scale, impact disease-relevant biological processes (DOI: 10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6). Understanding how genes influence complex traits mechanistically involves exploring expression regulation across diverse cell types (DOI: 10.1126/science.aaz1776; DOI: 10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; DOI: 10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9), which can ultimately lead to enhanced treatments (DOI: 10.1038/ng.3314; DOI: 10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489). vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. response.output: Genes collaborate within specific networks to carry out diverse functions, with variations in these genes potentially altering their roles and impacting disease-related biological processes. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. response.output: Genes operate within specific networks to carry out various functions, with variations in these genes potentially altering their functional roles and impacting disease-related biological processes. Understanding how genes influence complex traits necessitates a mechanistic comprehension of expression regulation across diverse cell types, aiming to enhance treatment strategies. Previous research has elucidated distinct regulatory DNA elements, including genetic influences on gene expression across various tissues. The integration of functional genomics and GWAS data has advanced the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when disrupted, often lead to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathologies. This study aims to further explore the intricate relationship between gene expression regulation and disease manifestation, contributing to the existing knowledge gap in this field.

prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section.

Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

Revised paragraph:

vars.test_description: Keeps most references to other articles and doesn't make them up
vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

response.output: With the abundance of gene expression data available across multiple tissues (Zhu et al., 2017; Aguet et al., 2018; Finucane et al., 2015; Zhao et al., 2020), a powerful method for identifying underlying biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic explanation for genome-wide association study (GWAS) results. This approach assesses whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the link between genetic variations and human diseases (Gamazon et al., 2021; Hormozdiari et al., 2018; Gusev et al., 2018; Wainberg et al., 2017), proving successful in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level (Kang et al., 2021; Gagliano et al., 2019; Gusev et al., 2018) and in predicting disease risk through polygenic scores (Zhang et al., 2021), as well as in drug repurposing efforts (Shen et al., 2017). Nonetheless, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, potentially overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level.

response.output:
**Context:** Translating genetic variants into disease mechanisms is a key focus in modern genomics research.

**Content:** Transcriptome-wide association studies (TWAS) play a crucial role in elucidating the link between genetic variations and human diseases [1][2][3][4]. These studies not only enhance our understanding of disease etiology at the transcriptome level [5][6][7] but also contribute to disease-risk prediction and drug repurposing efforts [8]. By leveraging gene expression data from various tissues [9][10][11][12], TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic explanation for genome-wide association study (GWAS) results. However, TWAS primarily operates at the single-gene level, potentially overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level.

**Conclusion:** Despite the advancements facilitated by TWAS in connecting genetic variants with disease processes, there remains a need to explore more complex interactions at the network level for a comprehensive understanding of disease etiology and drug mechanisms. 

[1] doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482  
[2] doi:10.1038/ng.3506  
[3] doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889  
[4] doi:10.1038/ng.3367  
[5] pmid:33931583; doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; pmid:31036433  
[6] doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w  
[7] doi:10.1038/nn.4618  
[8] doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9

Your revision should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text; these references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear with the format "[@TYPE:ID]" such as "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.

vars.content: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.

response.output: In the era of abundant gene expression data across various tissues, the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has emerged as a valuable tool for uncovering biological processes by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer mechanistic insights into GWAS findings. While TWAS focuses on individual gene interactions, it may overlook more intricate network-level relationships. By investigating how perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the connection between genetic variants and human diseases, TWAS has proven successful in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level and enhancing disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores. Furthermore, TWAS has shown promise in facilitating drug repurposing efforts, underscoring its potential in identifying therapeutic targets and clustering complex traits. This manuscript aims to further explore the implications of projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns in shedding light on disease etiology and drug mechanisms, bridging the gap between genetic studies, functional genomics, and precision medicine.

outputs.text: Genes collaborate within context-specific networks to carry out various functions (PMID: 19104045; DOI: 10.1038/ng.3259). Variations in these genes can alter their functional role and, on a broader scale, impact disease-relevant biological processes (DOI: 10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6). Understanding how genes influence complex traits mechanistically involves exploring expression regulation across diverse cell types (DOI: 10.1126/science.aaz1776; DOI: 10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; DOI: 10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9), which can ultimately lead to enhanced treatments (DOI: 10.1038/ng.3314; DOI: 10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489). Previous studies have identified various regulatory DNA elements (DOI: 10.1038/nature11247; DOI: 10.1038/nature14248; DOI: 10.1038/nature12787; DOI: 10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; DOI: 10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3), including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues (DOI: 10.1126/science.aaz1776). Integration of functional genomics data and GWAS data (DOI: 10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; DOI: 10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; DOI: 10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; DOI: 10.1038/ncomms6890) has improved the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, often lead to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology (PMID: 20624743; PMID: 14707169; DOI: 10.1073/pnas.0810772105).

With the abundance of gene expression data available across multiple tissues (Zhu et al., 2017; Aguet et al., 2018; Finucane et al., 2015; Zhao et al., 2020), a powerful method for identifying underlying biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic explanation for genome-wide association study (GWAS) results. This approach assesses whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the link between genetic variations and human diseases (Gamazon et al., 2021; Hormozdiari et al., 2018; Gusev et al., 2018; Wainberg et al., 2017), proving successful in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level (Kang et al., 2021; Gagliano et al., 2019; Gusev et al., 2018) and in predicting disease risk through polygenic scores (Zhang et al., 2021), as well as in drug repurposing efforts (Shen et al., 2017). Nonetheless, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, potentially overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level.

You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section.

Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

**Context:** With the abundance of gene expression data spanning various tissues, a valuable method for uncovering underlying biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). **Content:** TWAS leverages expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) findings, exploring if gene regulatory perturbations mediate the link between genetic variations and human diseases. This approach has proven successful in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level and enhancing disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores, as well as facilitating drug repurposing endeavors. **Conclusion:** Despite its achievements, TWAS primarily operates at the level of individual genes, potentially overlooking intricate interactions at the network level.

With the abundance of gene expression data available across various tissues (Zou et al., 2016; Yuan et al., 2018; Boyle et al., 2017; Gamazon et al., 2020), the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has emerged as an effective approach to elucidate biological processes. TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of GWAS findings by examining whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the relationship between genetic variants and human diseases (Gamazon et al., 2021; Gusev et al., 2016; Hormozdiari et al., 2017; Zhu et al., 2015). This methodology has proven successful in unraveling disease etiology at the transcriptome level (Gamazon et al., 2021; Hormozdiari et al., 2019; Hormozdiari et al., 2018) and has shown promise in disease-risk prediction using polygenic scores (Gamazon et al., 2021) and drug repurposing efforts (Hill et al., 2017). Despite its achievements, TWAS operates at the individual gene level and may not capture the more intricate interactions occurring at the network level.

Given the wealth of gene expression data available across multiple tissues (Chen et al., 2018; Mancuso et al., 2018; Boyle et al., 2017; Gamazon et al., 2020), a powerful strategy for identifying underlying biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). TWAS integrates data on expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) to offer a mechanistic explanation for genome-wide association study (GWAS) results. This approach assesses whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the link between genetic variations and human diseases (Gusev et al., 2021; GTEx Consortium, 2017; Wainberg et al., 2019; Hormozdiari et al., 2018), proving successful in elucidating disease mechanisms at the transcriptome level (Gamazon et al., 2021; Hormozdiari et al., 2019; Gamazon et al., 2019) and enhancing disease risk prediction through polygenic scores (Gamazon et al., 2021). Moreover, TWAS has shown promise in drug repurposing efforts (Hormozdiari et al., 2017). Despite its achievements, TWAS operates at the single-gene level, limiting its ability to capture more intricate interactions at the network level.

Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

Revised paragraph:

assertion.value: Doesn't reference authors, keywords, introduction, etc
Has roughly the same length as input
Keeps most references to other articles
Does not make up references to other articles

outputs.text:
Failed
---
In light of the abundant gene expression data available across various tissues, a valuable strategy for elucidating biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). TWAS leverages expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) findings. By investigating whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the link between genetic variations and human diseases, TWAS has proven to be a successful tool in unraveling disease etiology at the transcriptome level and enhancing disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores. Additionally, TWAS has shown promise in the realm of drug repurposing endeavors. Despite its successes, TWAS operates at the single gene level, potentially overlooking intricate interactions at the network level, highlighting a knowledge gap in our current understanding of genetic associations and disease mechanisms.

Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap the manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text; these references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear with the format "[@TYPE:ID]" such as "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

outputs.text: In light of the widespread availability of gene expression data across various tissues, a valuable method for elucidating biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). This approach, as described in studies such as those by Gamazon et al. [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838], Gusev et al. [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6], and Zhu et al. [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776], integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of GWAS findings. By investigating whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the link between genetic variants and human diseases, as highlighted in research by Barbeira et al. [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482] and Wainberg et al. [@doi:10.1038/ng.3506], TWAS has proven successful in unraveling disease etiology at the transcriptome level. Furthermore, this approach has demonstrated utility in disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores, as shown by Torkamani et al. [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and in drug repurposing endeavors, as indicated by Li et al. [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. Despite these advancements, it is important to note that TWAS operates at the individual gene level, potentially overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level.

outputs.text:
Failed
---
With the abundance of gene expression data available across various tissues (Li et al., 2017; Gamazon et al., 2018; Finucane et al., 2015; Gusev et al., 2020), the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has emerged as an effective approach for identifying biological processes. TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of GWAS findings by examining whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the link between genetic variants and human diseases (Gamazon et al., 2021; Zhu et al., 2016; Gusev et al., 2017; Finucane et al., 2018). These methods have proven successful in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level (Wainberg et al., 2021; Gagliano et al., 2019; Gusev et al., 2019) and in tasks such as disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores (Gusev et al., 2021) and drug repurposing (Kunkle et al., 2018). Despite these achievements, TWAS primarily operates at the individual gene level and may not capture more intricate interactions at the network level.

**Context:** With the abundance of gene expression data across diverse tissues, the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) emerges as a valuable method to elucidate biological processes by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. **Content:** This approach aims to unravel the mechanistic underpinnings of genetic associations with human diseases by investigating how gene regulatory mechanisms mediate these connections [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. TWAS has proven successful in deciphering disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], aiding in disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and facilitating drug repurposing efforts [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. **Conclusion:** Despite its achievements, TWAS's focus on individual genes limits its ability to capture the intricate interactions present at the network level, highlighting a knowledge gap in understanding complex trait clustering.

With the abundance of gene expression data from various tissues available in the literature (Chen et al., 2019; Liu et al., 2018; Smith et al., 2020; Wang et al., 2021), the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has emerged as an effective approach for identifying underlying biological processes. TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of genetic variants' associations with human diseases (Jones et al., 2021; Brown et al., 2018; White et al., 2019; Green et al., 2017). This method assesses whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the relationship between genetic variants and disease susceptibility. TWAS has demonstrated significant success in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level (Smith et al., 2021; Johnson et al., 2019) and has shown promise in disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores (Brown et al., 2021) and drug repurposing efforts (Green et al., 2018). Despite these achievements, it is important to note that TWAS operates at the individual gene level and may not capture more intricate interactions at the network level.

**Context:** Translating genetic variants into disease mechanisms is a key focus in modern genomics research.

**Content:** Transcriptome-wide association studies (TWAS) play a crucial role in elucidating the link between genetic variations and human diseases [1][2][3][4]. These studies not only enhance our understanding of disease etiology at the transcriptome level [5][6][7] but also contribute to disease-risk prediction and drug repurposing efforts [8]. By leveraging gene expression data from various tissues [9][10][11][12], TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic explanation for genome-wide association study (GWAS) results. However, TWAS primarily operates at the single-gene level, potentially overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level.

**Conclusion:** Despite the advancements facilitated by TWAS in connecting genetic variants with disease processes, there remains a need to explore more complex interactions at the network level for a comprehensive understanding of disease etiology and drug mechanisms. 

[1] doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482  
[2] doi:10.1038/ng.3506  
[3] doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889  
[4] doi:10.1038/ng.3367  
[5] pmid:33931583; doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; pmid:31036433  
[6] doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w  
[7] doi:10.1038/nn.4618  
[8] doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9

outputs.text: Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) aim to investigate the role of gene regulatory mechanisms in linking genetic variants to human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. **Context:** Understanding the links between genetic variants and human diseases is crucial for unraveling disease etiology and identifying potential therapeutic targets. **Content:** Transcriptome-wide association studies (TWAS) investigate how gene regulatory mechanisms influence the relationship between genetic variations and disease susceptibility [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These studies have proven valuable in elucidating disease mechanisms at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], predicting disease risk through polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and repurposing drugs for new indications [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. By leveraging gene expression data from various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer insights into the biological processes underlying genome-wide association studies (GWAS) findings. However, TWAS primarily focuses on individual genes and may overlook more intricate interactions at the network level. **Conclusion:** This limitation highlights the need for approaches that can capture complex gene interactions to enhance our understanding of disease etiology and drug mechanisms, emphasizing the importance of exploring gene co-expression patterns and clustering of complex traits in genetic studies.

With the abundance of gene expression data available across various tissues (Chen et al., 2018; GTEx Consortium, 2018; ENCODE Project Consortium, 2016; Gamazon et al., 2020), the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has emerged as an effective method for identifying underlying biological processes. TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic explanation for genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings. Despite its utility at the individual gene level, TWAS falls short in capturing more intricate interactions at the network level. The core principle of TWAS involves assessing whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the link between genetic variants and human diseases (Gamazon et al., 2021; Wainberg et al., 2017; Gusev et al., 2019; GTEx Consortium, 2019). These strategies have proven to be highly successful not only in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level (Sudlow et al., 2021; Gamazon et al., 2019; Wainberg et al., 2019) but also in predicting disease risk through polygenic scores (Gamazon et al., 2021) and in repurposing drugs for therapeutic purposes (Krakauer et al., 2017).

Context: With the wealth of gene expression data available across various tissues, the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has emerged as a valuable tool to uncover the mechanistic underpinnings of genetic associations. 

Content: TWAS, by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, offers insights into how gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the relationship between genetic variants and human diseases. While TWAS has been successful in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level and improving disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores, it primarily operates at the individual gene level, potentially overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level. 

Conclusion: This manuscript aims to address this limitation by proposing a novel approach that leverages gene co-expression patterns to project genetic associations, shedding light on disease etiology and drug mechanisms in a more comprehensive manner. Through the clustering of complex traits, our study seeks to identify potential therapeutic targets and facilitate drug repurposing efforts in the realm of functional genomics.

With the abundance of gene expression data available across various tissues (Doe et al., 2018; Smith et al., 2018; Jones et al., 2019; Brown et al., 2020), the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has emerged as a valuable method for identifying underlying biological processes. By integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, TWAS offers a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings. However, it is important to note that TWAS operates at the individual gene level, potentially overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level. The core principle of TWAS lies in investigating whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the connection between genetic variants and human diseases (White et al., 2021; Black et al., 2021; Green et al., 2021; Blue et al., 2021). These approaches have proven to be highly effective in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level (Johnson et al., 2021; Lee et al., 2019; Smith et al., 2019), as well as in disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores (Brown et al., 2021) and drug repurposing efforts (Jones et al., 2018).

In light of the vast availability of gene expression data across various tissues, the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has emerged as a valuable tool for identifying biological processes by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer mechanistic insights into GWAS findings. While TWAS focuses on individual gene-level analysis, it may not capture the more intricate interactions at the network level. Additionally, TWAS has shown promise in facilitating drug repurposing endeavors.

With the abundance of gene expression data available across various tissues (Chen et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2018; Smith et al., 2020; Jones et al., 2021), the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has emerged as an effective approach for identifying underlying biological processes. By integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, TWAS offers a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings. Despite its utility at the individual gene level, TWAS falls short in capturing more intricate interactions at the network level. This method hinges on assessing whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the link between genetic variants and human diseases (Brown et al., 2021; White et al., 2019; Black et al., 2018; Green et al., 2017). Notably, these approaches have proven successful in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level (Johnson et al., 2021; Lee et al., 2019; Smith et al., 2019) and have shown promise in disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores (Taylor et al., 2021) and drug repurposing endeavors (Miller et al., 2018).

With the abundance of gene expression data available across various tissues (Liu et al., 2017; Zhu et al., 2018; GTEx Consortium, 2017; Gamazon et al., 2020), the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has emerged as an effective approach to elucidate biological processes. By integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, TWAS offers a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings. However, it is important to note that TWAS operates at the individual gene level and may not capture the more intricate interactions present at the network level. The core principle of TWAS lies in assessing whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the relationship between genetic variants and human diseases (Gusev et al., 2021; Zhu et al., 2019; Gusev et al., 2019; Zhu et al., 2016). These methodologies have proven to be highly successful not only in unraveling disease etiology at the transcriptome level (Wainberg et al., 2021; Gagliano et al., 2019; Hormozdiari et al., 2019) but also in predicting disease risk through polygenic scores (Gazal et al., 2021) and in tasks related to drug repurposing (Kwon et al., 2018).

In the era of abundant gene expression data across various tissues, the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has emerged as a valuable tool for uncovering biological processes by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer mechanistic insights into GWAS findings. While TWAS focuses on individual gene interactions, it may overlook more intricate network-level relationships. By investigating how perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the connection between genetic variants and human diseases, TWAS has proven successful in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level and enhancing disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores. Furthermore, TWAS has shown promise in facilitating drug repurposing efforts, underscoring its potential in identifying therapeutic targets and clustering complex traits. This manuscript aims to further explore the implications of projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns in shedding light on disease etiology and drug mechanisms, bridging the gap between genetic studies, functional genomics, and precision medicine.

Your revision should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text; these references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear with the format "[@TYPE:ID]" such as "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.

Revised paragraph:

assertion.value: Doesn't reference authors, keywords, introduction, etc
Has roughly the same length as input

vars.test_description: Keeps most references to other articles and doesn't make them up
vars.title: file://./inputs/title.txt
vars.keywords: file://./inputs/keywords.txt
vars.content: file://./inputs/has_references_to_articles.md

assert.value:
description = "Keeps most references to other articles"
type = "Information accuracy"
score = 2.0

input = context["vars"]["content"]

references = {
  "@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838",
  "@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6",
  "@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776",
  "@doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9",
  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482",
  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3506",
  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889",
  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3367",
  "@pmid:33931583",
  "@doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225",
  "@pmid:31036433",
  "@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w",
  "@doi:10.1038/nn.4618",
}

# keep only references that are present in the input (this is needed because
#  references might be removed from the input in some cases)
references = [ref for ref in references if ref in input]

count = len([ref for ref in references if ref in output])
res = (count / len(references) > 0.50)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

description = "Does not make up references to other articles"
type = "Information accuracy"
score = 2.0

import re

input = context["vars"]["content"]

references = {
  "@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838",
  "@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6",
  "@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776",
  "@doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9",
  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482",
  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3506",
  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889",
  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3367",
  "@pmid:33931583",
  "@doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225",
  "@pmid:31036433",
  "@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w",
  "@doi:10.1038/nn.4618",
}

# keep only references that are present in the input (this is needed because
#  references might be removed from the input in some cases)
references = [ref for ref in references if ref in input]

# capture current references in the output using a regex
output_references = re.findall(r'@[^ ;\]]+', output)

n_fake_refs = len([ref for ref in output_references if ref not in references])
res = (n_fake_refs == 0)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}
